Pre-Game Insights: The South Africans claimed a record fourth triumph in rugby, winning a thunderous, controversy-strewn classic by a single point.
New Zealand have beaten South Africa six times in eight meetings in cricket World Cup matches.
South Africa is among the biggest batting teams at the tournament and showed resilience by beating Pakistan by one wicket in a close match.
New Zealand's Lockie Ferguson, Kane Williamson, and Mark Chapman are carrying significant injuries.
The match is more about determining the semifinal line-up, with both teams confident of making it to the semis.
New Zealand's remaining opponents in the league stage are Pakistan and Sri Lanka, while South Africa will face unbeaten India at Eden Gardens.
The match will be played on November 1, 2023, at 14:00 IST at Maharashtra Cricket Association Stadium, Pune.
The pitch is expected to produce a small target, with 260 not reached in either of the first innings in the two matches played here in the tournament.
Kane Williamson has been ruled out of the match, and New Zealand is awaiting news on Lockie Ferguson's Achilles and Mark Chapman's calf.
New Zealand has made four of the top 20 totals in the tournament, with Rachin Ravindra, Daryl Mitchell, and Devon Conway scoring centuries.
Mitchell Santner and Matt Henry are New Zealand's two most successful bowlers, and Glenn Phillips' off-spin has become more frontline.
Kagiso Rabada missed the match against Pakistan due to lower back spasms but should be good to go on Wednesday.
South Africa owns four of the 20 biggest totals at this World Cup, with Quinton de Kock scoring half of their six hundreds.
Marco Jansen and Gerald Coetzee are among the leading 10 wicket-takers for South Africa, but the team has been liable to leak runs.
Post-Match Reflections: Tom Latham expressed that his team can feel the support from back home despite the nation's obsession with the rugby World Cup.
Rob Walter reflected on South Africa's ability to handle pressure, stating that winning key moments in pressure games is a positive sign.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Two of the three centuries in World Cup games between New Zealand and South Africa were scored in the same match at the Wanderers in 2003.
Jacob Oram's 4/39 in the 2011 quarterfinal in Dhaka is the only instance of a bowler claiming more than three wickets in World Cup matches between these teams.
Two of New Zealand's six World Cup wins were in knockout games: the 2011 quarterfinal and the 2015 semifinal.
